news uk-news giles-coren-claims-masked-ninnies-"The Chase: Bradley Walsh cringes at Giles Corens dance moveByLorna HughesAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments Giles Corenaposs latest column attacks people still wearing face masks after Plan B rules were lted, branding them cringing losers afraid of their own shadows.The writer and TV presenter blasted masked ninnies, saying they had post-pandemic health hysteria, adding that some were on a courtesy crusade.The sour comments were in his latest Sunday Times column, in which he described his journey on the London Underground on Thursday - which was the day that mandatory mask-wearing was axed in England.He said most of his fellow passengers still wore face coverings and debated why they had chosen to wear them He stressed he was not an anti-masker, but said they had sheeplike obedience to yesterdayaposs rules.  He wrote: Perhaps, I thought, they were wearing them against air pollution, which is bad at the moment. Or because it was a cold morning and they actively enjoyed the warmth of their foetid breath circulating inside the germy fabric  Or perhaps, I supposed, these masked ninnies were still so afraid of the now-harmless bug that they were prepared to endure the mild discomfort and inconvenience that comes with the illusion of security provided by a mask.  Or perhaps, in their post-pandemic health hysteria, they were hoping now to protect themselves against flu, measles, hepatitis ... even cancer  . While masks are no longer a legal requirement in England, there are still some settings where they are recommended. Londoners need to keep wearing them when using Transport for London services.  While London Mayor Sadiq Khanaposs demands are not enforceable by police and do not carry a fine, face masks will remain a condition of carriage on TfL services. That means you can be refused admission to a Tube or bus without one. Mr Khan urged the PM to rethink scrapping face masks altogether.He said: Wearing a face covering is one of the single most important and easiest things we can all do to prevent the spread of Covid- and the Government should rethink their plans.Some supermarkets will continue to either ask or suggest that shoppers wear a mask. Sainsbury’s and John Lewis said their customers will be asked to wear masks, though the latter acknowledged it will ultimately come down to “personal choice”. title: girl 11 using feeding tube
story: Exclusive: Girl, , using feeding tube to eat a year after Covid left her too weak to moveTillie Adams, , from east London, spent weeks in hospital and is often too ill to go to school as she battles Long Covid after contracting the virus in January last yearTillie Adams has been battling Long Covid for more than a year Image: tilliesjourney InstagramByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Jan |commentsA brave schoolgirl who has to be fed through a tube has voiced her anger at the Long Covid nightmare robbing her of a normal childhood. Tillie Adams, , is one of an estimated , under-s suffering with the long-term effects of the virus in the UK - with , ill for more than a year. During her  month ordeal Tillie has spent weeks in hospital and is often too ill to go to school.Her weight plummeted dangerously as she struggled to eat after falling ill with coronavirus last January, and she still suffers from debilitating sickness a year later.After her condition baffled medics for months, the schoolgirl was eventually told she had Post Covid Infection Syndrome, and has had a NG tube, which provides vital nutrients, since last summer. Long Covid is thought to affect around one in  children under the age of , while . per cent of those aged  to  are believed to have it.  Tillie, who now struggles to walk up the stairs at her home in Hoxton, east London, and has fainted several times in recent months, said: Sometimes I get so angry, I want to go to school, but itaposs just so hard, some days I canapost because Iaposm just so tired and so washed out. When she was first diagnosed with Covid she suffered with a temperature, aches and pains and lost her smell and taste.Her mum Kelly was told that Tillie should start to feel better within a fortnight, but weeks later she was still suffering from headaches, stomach pains and dficulty eating.Tillie, who used to be full of energy and enjoyed playing outside before she became ill, said: I just felt confused, I was just so scared, I didnapost know what to do. At first Iaposd just stay in bed because I was scared to move.  She spent two weeks in hospital after losing a stone in a matter of weeks as medics desperately tried to work out what was wrong. The more weight she was losing, the weaker she became, said Kelly, . She went grey and her lips split open, it was awful. It took a month before her energy levels picked up. She couldnapost manage the stairs, she was sometimes falling up the stairs and when she got to the top she was so light headed she would almost faint. She still gets those effects now. Sheaposs like a totally dferent child. At first Tillie was unable to dress herself, and she still needs help washing her hair.  Tillie, who is now helping researchers at University College Hospital in London understand Long Covid in children, was initially told she would only require an NG tube for two weeks. But nine months later she is still using one as she makes a phasedto school, aiming to do a half day five days a week. Brave Tillie missed out on much of her final year at primary school, but is desperate not to fall behind during her y recovery. She wants to push herself and she wants to be at school, said Kelly. But theyaposve told her she wonapost be able to go back to school full time until at least Year . Since October sheaposs only managed three weeks where sheaposs managed five half days. The rest of the time sheaposs in bed, sheaposs so washed out.  Sheaposs really worried about falling behind, but she knows that this could go on for years.Determined to show that Covid isnapost just a virus that affects adults, and keen to show others going through a similar ordeal that they are not alone, Tillie last year set up an Instagram account documenting her journey.It has amassed thousands of followers and the family have been inundated with messages of goodwill. She said: Itaposs been amazing. I want to raise awareness for others so they knowthey have it theyaposre not alone. The night before speaking to The Mirror, Tillie had spoken to another girl who was having an NG tube fitted.  Kelly said: At first I was really nervous, but she said: aposI want to help people in the same position and show that kids are suffering tooapos. Children are often forgotten about, you donapost see anything about kids with Long Covid, but when we were in hospital I spoke to lots of other parents who were going through the same thing. Latest figures from the Office for National Statisticsestimates that , children with Long Covid had to limit their activity a little in December, while , were severely restricted. It is believed that around . million people of all ages had Long Covid at the end of last year - just under two per cent of the population. Sammie Mcfarland, founder of charity Long Covid Kids, said the organisation is supporting just under , families across the UK, with numbers rising steeply. Last week alone more than  registered for support, she said. Itaposs getting worse, Sammie told The Mirror, adding that she is aware of several children who require NG tubes after contracting Covid. There are a lot of children with issues like Tillieaposs. We urgently need GP training in recognising Long Covid and we need a strong awareness campaign that accepts children are experiening Covid harm. Weaposre not seeing large numbers of people saying theyaposre back to  per cent, many children arenapost getting any better at all. That for me is the largest concern.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON British Medical JournalEducationHospitalsSchoolsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: girl 5 misdiagnosed constipation almost
story: Girl, , misdiagnosed with constipation for almost a year told she has cancerLittle Dulcie OKelly, , from Telford, Shropshire, was taken to the doctor last January, but her parents were told she had constipation despite consistent swelling and stomach painsDulcie has stage  cancer Image: @dulcies_neuroblastoma_journey   CATERS NEWSByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Jan |comments A bloated five-year-old who was told for a year she simply had constipation after complaining of tummy pains, has been diagnosed with cancer.Little Dulcie OaposKelly from Telford, Shropshire, was taken to the doctors last January, but her parents say they were told her swollen stomach was caused by constipation. Her mum, Debbie , pushed for more answers, believing she had a food intolerance and eventually in November last year, Dulcie was given a scan. A biopsy the following month revealed she had stage  Neuroblastoma - an aggressive form of cancer which had spread to her pelvis, bone marrow, legs and spine. Dulcie is now going through intense chemotherapy in a bid to save her le. Mum of one, Debbie, said: The diagnosis was such a shock. Our entire world has crashed around us and never in a million years did we suspect it was cancer. We had never heard of Neuroblastoma. Dulcieaposs parents say doctors have not told them how likely Dulcie is to survive and the youngster is now on her fth round of chemotherapy. The mum from Telford, Shropshire, said: Doctors have told us that the cancer is treatable but I want parents to know the signs becausewe had known sooner what Dulcie was suffering with, it may not have spread so aggressively through her body. We were completely unaware that her symptoms could be something so le-threatening and all we can do now is pray doctors have still caught it in time. The scan found a cancerous mass measuring cm by cm in her stomach.  Debbie said: Neuroblastoma is the second most aggressive cancer in children. We need to stop the tumour in her stomach growing and spreading further around her body. Doctors are also looking at surgery to remove as much of the tumour as possible - after she has completed seven rounds of chemotherapy. Debbie added: The symptoms I want to make other parents aware of include a swollen tummy, constipation. It can cause children to walk quite unsteadily and have a weakness in their legs. A loss of energy, weight loss and loss of appetite are all signs too. I want to raise as much awareness as possible of this terrible disease because it was easily mistaken for something . The family have also launched a £, fundraising appeal to pay for lesaving treatment in the US.Debbie added: The treatment plan for Dulcie in the UK is for  to  months, itaposs a long road to recovery and could take two years to be in remission. There is the potential that she will never be cancer-free because of the type of cancer it is. If the treatment in the UK doesnapost work, the family could then need to take Dulcie to America. Debbie said: We have started to fundraise for this possibility now because we need to know we have enough funds for the treatment in the US. It would need to start  days after the end of the treatment here, so we canapost risk having to fundraise closer to the time and not having the money to take her. Whilst we hope going to America wonapost be necessary, we have to be prepared to do everything possible for our little girl. If in  months we are in the position that we wonapost require this lesaving trip then any funds raised will be either passed to another family who does need it or donated to several childhood cancer charities. For now, the family are taking each day as it comes and focusing on Dulcieaposs chemotherapy. Debbie said: Dulcie is a superstar, she smiles through it even when she is tired and she bounces back. She is very grown-up for her age, she knows she has cancer but she asks questions that I canapost answer, she wants to know why she has cancer.  It breaks my heart to see her going through this. I have my good and bad days, but her strength gives me strength and most days she is coping really well. Debbie added: When we got the diagnoses I cried in disbelief, how can my daughter have cancer  We have gone through every emotion possible, thinking why was it not spotted sooner. You donapost think it will ever happen to your child, it is a rare cancer but GPs and parents need to recognise the symptoms andyou have any concerns, push for more tests. title: girl invited compete country couldnt
story: Girl invited to compete for country couldnt afford to go so locals paid for herMelissa Ainslie is just -years-old but shes a bowling protégé and was asked to represent Scotland in an international competition, but when she couldnt afford to go her local community rallied around herMelissa Ainslie is set to represent Scotland after her local community raised the money she needed to attendByJohn BettAudience WriterSarah Ward:,  Jan |comments A young girl is set to represent her country in an international bowling competition after her local community rallied around her and raised the money needed for her to attend.Melissa Ainslie is just  but she is a keen bowler and has been invited to compete for Scotland at the European Youth Championships, which are held in France in April. But it was going to cost Melissaaposs family around £,, and her parents, Kelly, , and Allyn, , were struggling to pay for the nine-day trip. Now Melissa is set to compete as enough money was donated by friends, family, and the local community - who all wanted to see the youngster represent them. What do you think about the generous fundraising  Let us know in the comments...Melissa, who already has  trophies, said: Iaposm really happy everyone has tried to help, itaposs incredible. Iaposm going for my gran and the people who helped me to get there. I am one of eight people picked to represent Scotland. I hope there might be more opportunities to go around the world. I learnt when I was younger and I got it from my parents and grandparents. I would like to do it professionally when Iaposm older and go into coaching.  Melissa is putting in three hours a week training at Deer Park Country Club, Livingston, West Lothian, in preparation - after having  months with no bowling at all due to lockdowns. And sheaposs able to go after generous donors raised £, so Melissa can attend to the competition. She said she will be thinking of gran Anne Ainslie, , who died on October , , and inspired her love of the sport. Melissa said: My grandparents got me into the league and it got more competitive. The competitions are all over Scotland, Iaposve made a lot of friends through it. The Mirror is committed to more hopeful news. We recognise the news agenda can sometimes feel overwhelmingly negative.And while itaposs our job to keep you informed and hold those in power to account, we are making a commitment to also report more hopeful news. We will celebrate the people, places and movements that are bringing good into the world and, more than that, we will dig beneath the surface of important issues with the aim of finding hope.We will be firm in our convictions - but always fair-minded. By sharing solutions to problems, we can do more good and feel better about the world around us. Because we believe you deserve it. #mirrormorehopefulFollow on Twitter @mirrormorehope And follow Mirror More Hopeful on FacebookFor more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. Itaposs the first time Iaposll be going abroad to represent Scotland. Youaposve got to work out what styles works best and what you are comfortable with. If there are lots of people around I just try to ignore everyone and focus. There was a competition in March , and then  months off. In September last year I went back. I just feel like thataposs my comfort zone.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: gran 82 dubbed britains most
story: Gran, , dubbed Britains most loyal guest after going to same hotel for  yearsAnne Dunn, , from Lichfield, Staffordshire, has spent around £, on her regular stays at the three-star Colwall Park Hotel in Malvern after first going in A gran has been dubbed Britain’s most loyal hotel guest Image: Courtesy of Anne Dunn   SWNSByAdam AspinallNews ReporterLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Jan |commentsA gran has been dubbed Britain’s most loyal guest having ed to the same hotel – for the last  years.Anne Dunn, , from Lichfield, Staffordshire, has spent around £, on her regular stays at the three-star Colwall Park Hotel in leafy Malvern, Worcestershire.She first went to the hotel as a two-year-old in  when her father Harry Lucas, who worked as an accountant for the owners. Anne stayed at the hotel again following the end of World War Two in  and played with the owner’s son who was around the same age.  Since then, Anne has ed to her favourite hotel several times a year, often spending Christmas and Easter holidays there. Anne, who lives  miles away from the £-a-night hotel said: “I had a lot of association through my father. “When we started visiting the hotel in the mid-s my father was the hotel’s accountant.  “We used to go for every holiday, from Christmas to Easter and even the summer holidays.” Anne continued toto the hotel after marrying her husband John in  until he died last June. The gran-of-seven has continued her regular visits to the hotel with her daughter Emma, , and her puppy Bronte. She added: “My husband died in June last year but we have kept on going to the hotel, but now with my daughter.  “It is real value for money and we love going back there each year. “The place is my home away from home. I just love staying there.” She added: “The old ledgers are still kept in the hotel. I had a look the last time I visited, and they have them on display.  “It was a wonderful trip down memory lane.” Anne has already booked to stay at her favourite hotel this Easter. She added: “No matter how many times I’ve been to Colwall Park, I always look forward to my stays.” A spokesperson for the hotel said: “As the hotel’s longest ing guest, Colwall Park has been an integral part of her le that she has shared with friends and family over so many years. “Through sharing her trips with her children in her later years, she continues to spread the warmth she feels when visiting Colwall Park with her loved ones, and now with her new puppy too.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Holidays" data-immediate"data-immediate"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Sign Up!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news horror-haunted-doll-weeps-tears-"TikTok user finds a haunted doll in San DiegoByBeth KilgallonGraeme Murray:,  Jan |comments A haunted doll which aposweeps tears of acid and tries to set itself on fireapos has been rescued by a ghost hunter after a house fire.Annie the doll, similar to those seen in classic horror movies, was bought by a supernatural fan calling himself Matt Paranormal who was intrigued by its background.The horric doll was found in a house fire in which the owners died, making it all the more terrying. Matt, , from Wrexham, Wales, told the Daily Star : “After reading about her history with the house fire, I knew I wanted to buy her.”After buying Annie two years ago, Matt experienced a host of strange incidents including the doll trying to set itself on fire.  He claims its previous owners appeared next to her in images and witnessed the doll crying acid tears. The supernatural fan spotted Annie at an auction in the US and was keen to buy her. But the doll did not cost a huge amount of money and Matt fitted her with monitoring equipment to detect any paranormal activity which was happening.  He said: “She cost me £. After I had her imported to the UK, I had paranormal equipment installed into her as I thought her previous owners’ spirits would be attached to her. “It wasn’t until last year that Annie actually started to cry. “I believe that when she cries it is her ‘attachments’ way of showing emotions. He says the dollaposs weeping followed the death of her owners who are in denial that they have passed away. This he claims means they are aposdemonsapos who will not let go of their former lives. “Annie’s tears are acidic which is demonic. As her previous owners haven’t accepted that they are dead, it means they are classed as demons.”  Matt revealed: “Annie is now kept in a glass box and is under -hour surveillance because she keeps trying to set herself on fire. “Every now and then her clothes get a little bit more singed and charred, and her face is much darker now. “Annie loves fire and last year, each of my five team members, all had something to do with fire happen to their house – all on the same day.”  The doll has been compared with horror movie toys Chucky and Annabelle who have terried cinema goers for decades and the horror continues to intrigue them. Matt said people are clamouring to see a a hunted doll similar to ones they have witnessed in films. He said: “Annie is very popular with people who come and visit our HQ.  “Some people love the thrill of knowing there is a real haunted doll in front of them. “However, some people have walked in the door and walked straight back out again after seeing her. title: kate middletons sister wants transform
story: Kate Middletons sister wants to transform farm into exciting tourist hotspotKate Middletons sister Pippa and her husband James Matthews bought Buckleberry Farm in Berkshire in  - and have now submitted plans to the local council to transform it into a child-friendly attractionKates sister Pippa with her husband James Image: GettyByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan |commentsThe Duchess of Cambridgeaposs sister and her husband look to be transforming a farm into an exciting updated tourist attraction for children.Pippa and her husband James Matthews bought Buckleberry Farm - a rundown petting zoo and deer park close to the mansion where Kateaposs parents live in Berkshire - back in .And now theyaposve submitted plans to the local council to build an indoor play barn for children, a cafe and a farm shop with outdoor seating. It is thought that the couple and their business partners aim to spend around £, on the upgrade.Before Pippa and James bought the farm, the -acre site consisted of a -acre deer safari park with a cafe and other buildings for livestock, reports BerkshireLive.  A planning application from October  details plans to refurbish and make an extension to an existing visitor barn as well as associated structures, including a new storage building and the amendment of a public right of way. The plans say visitor numbers will be capped at  a day to prevent the village from being swamped and they predict the venture will pump £. million into the local economy. The new plans for Bucklebury Farm are currently awaiting the response of West Berkshire Councilaposs planning committee. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. However, the couple may already have come up with their name for the new venture - they have registered a company called Pippa’s Playground. Pippa, , can be regularly spotted in a wax jacket and wellies overseeing things at the farm. It is also home to a deer safari park, which holds an extensive deer herd with four dferent breeds.The farm, where Prince George has been spotted in the past, offers tractor rides during the spring and summer months. There are also walking tours, pat-a pet, meet the goats, pony grooming, egg collecting and donkey brushing for kids.Play areas include an outdoor adventure zone with a zip line, an obstacle course and picnic benches. news uk-news large-unmanned-ship-seen-floating-"Kent: Unmanned vessel spotted on the marshesByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments A large ship which appears to be sailing without a crew or captain has been spotted floating off the English coast. It was first spotted in the waters of Kent, and is thought to be drting from Upchurch towards Swale. Itaposs thought the vessel lost its mooring, causing it to float away, Kent Live reports.The owners of the boat are aware that itaposs drting and a tug boat has been sent to the floating ship. A statement from the HM Coastguard said: At approx. .am today , HM Coastguard received multiple  calls from members of the public concerned about a vessel having broken free of its moorings on the River Medway near Lower Halstow.  Medway and Sheppey Coastguard Rescue Teams were sent alongside the Sheerness RNLI all-weather leboat. The vessel ran aground on the marshes, the owner has been informed and is arranging a tug. Sheppey Coastguard Rescue Team will provide safety cover until the vessel is secured.A Twitter account named Upchurch Matters posted: An apparently unmanned vessel , has lost its mooring and is pictured drting towards Lower Halstow. The coastguard has been contacted. title: madeleine mccann prime suspect worked
story: Madeleine McCann prime suspect worked as handy man at resort where she vanishedChristian Brueckner, who is in prison having raped a pensioner, carried out repair works at the Ocean Club in Praia da Luz, Portugal where Maedleine McCann went missing in Christian Brueckner worked at the resort where Maddie went missing, it has been reported Image: REX ShutterstockByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Jan  The main suspect in the Madeleine McCann disappearance worked at the resort where she was last seen, a documentary has claimed.A new investigation into the young Brit suggests that convicted rapist Christian Brueckner carried out repair works at the Ocean Club in Praia da Luz, Portugal multiple times. Maddie disappeared from the resort in  and hasnapost been seen since. Her family still hope she will be found alive. The German TV channel SAT. documentary claims that Brueckner, , was very familiar with Ocean Club, as well as surrounding parts of the Algarve. When Maddie disappeared from the hotel room where her parents had left her, the rapist was no more than five minutes away - phone data analyses by SAT. suggests. In letters reportedly from Brueckner, who is currently in prison for raping a pensioner, he admits to trafficking drugs in a battered hippy van around the time of the disappearance.  He denies claims that he abducted Maddie however, suggesting to do so would be absurd... as starting a nuclear war or slaughtering a chicken. He wrote: I was never caught by the police because I followed a few key principles. Where possible, only driving during the day so that my battered hippy bus didnapost attract attention, only driving on the roads I needed to and, most importantly never provoking the police. So that means not committing any crimes, certainly not abducting anyone. Brueckner was named as the prime suspect in the Maddie case in  by German prosecutors. They remain convinced he was responsible for the youngsteraposs disappearance, but have not brought any charges despite an intense investigation. Brueckner claims he is happy to sit back and relax and just wait for their findings.  His lover at the time, Nicole Fehlinger, , says he told her he liked the bodies of pre-pubescent girls. The documentary also makes claims that Brueckner swapped child abuse images and depraved online messages with an undertaker. The mortician gave “a full confession” when quizzed by German police and admitted he was a “regular customer” of the convicted paedophile. It is understood material he handed over to officers now forms part of evidence being used against Brueckner. The undertaker, also a convicted sex offender, cannot be named for legal reasons – but he has spoken to the makers of a new documentary about the case, being shown tomorrow night on German TV channel Sat.. The film’s lead investigator Jutta Rabe told the Sunday People: “I’m not sure what he paid but he confirmed they regularly swapped material, all of which he has handed over to detectives. We haven’t been able to confirmthey were business partners but he insisted he... has completely mended his ways.” The undertaker, who lives alone, said he was interviewed by the BKA – Germany’s FBI. Miss Rabe said: “He was given a choice, ‘You either admit it and help us then go into therapy or go to prison’. He chose co-operation.” The TV documentary also includes a reconstruction of the evening of the toddleraposs disappearance. It will be screened in Germany later today. title: mum considered ending life after
story: Mum considered ending her le after suffering crippling pain from hernia meshRoseanna Clarkin, from Scotland, says she was in so much pain last month she asked for ­guidance about how to legally end her own le after years of struggling with a hernia meshRoseanna Clarkin has called for mesh to no longer be used in the treatment of hernias Image: DAILY RECORDByVivienne AitkenHealth  Education Editor:,  Jan |commentsA mum considered ending her own le due to the crippling pain of a mesh implant. Roseanna Clarkin has suffered excruciating pain since medics used mesh products to repair damage caused by a hernia.Now she wants the use of mesh in hernia operations to be suspended, as it has for vaginal mesh following years of suffering by thousands of women, the Daily Record reported. The -year-old says she was in so much pain last month she asked for ­guidance about how to legally end her own le. Roseanna said: It sent me to a very dark place. I contacted Euthanasia UK. I asked how I could legally do this is Scotland. Roseanna tearfully admitted: I said to my husband, aposI have had enough of fightingapos. When I was going to the doctoraposs after my op, I wasnapost believed. They told me it was all in my head and even told my husband Brendan aposDonapost get roped into thisapos.  Roseanna believes that her mesh has moved within her, but she claims a doctor told her the issue was in her head. She first began suffering from health problems in , when the otherwise fit and active mum-of-three felt a sharp stabbing pain. Her GP said she had an umbilical herniation and sent her to the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital, Glasgow, where she was told no op was needed and to work on her abdominal muscle. The pain worsened two weeks later and she ed to her GP. A hospital surgeon told her he would need to operate and would use pig skin and dissolvable stitches - something they described as the gold standard treatment - and that she would be back in the gym in three weeks. There was no mention of using mesh to carry out the repair. The first indication of complications came when Roseanna suffered a heart rate of more than  beats per minute following the operation. She said: I now know it was a sign of the mesh being rejected by my body. At pm that night my husband was told they couldnapost stabilise my heart and they didnapost knowI was going to make it. Her sons Ryan, William and Cameron said goodbye just in case. From day one she was in excruciating pain, and it hasnapost improved since. She said: I got sent to pain specialists and my GP was constantly writing to the surgeon to say he would have to review me but the surgeon kept cancelling appointments. It was  months after the operation before I met with him again. He told me there was nothing wrong with me and whatever I had was nothing to do with the operation. I was so upset but he grabbed me by the arm and put me out his room. Roseanna asked for a second opinion in  and only then discovered the use of mesh in her op. She has been in and out of hospital regularly since, and has been diagnosed with ing neurological disorder, fibromyalgia and trigeminal neuralgia – sudden, severe facial pain. Roseanna explained: The mesh is compromising my nerves and sending wrong signals back to the brain. A surgeon offering a second opinion told her the mesh was causing her problems and needed to be removed. He could not perform the operation himself, but vowed to find someone who could. Now Roseanna is awaiting surgery, which has not taken place because of the problems she now has with her heart. She said: The longer itaposs in, the more dficult it is to remove it because it merges with your skin and the longer it is in, the worse my condition is getting. Roseanna has launched a campaign calling for the suspension of mesh in hernia operations, with a petition which is going through the public ­petitions committee at Holyrood. To date, more than  patients or their families have written to the committee about their experiences with hernia mesh implants. Labouraposs health spokeswoman, Jackie Baillie, who campaigned for vaginal mesh ops to be suspended, called for an urgent review of the uses of mesh for other procedures. She said: It has taken years for the serious problems caused for women who had transvaginal mesh used in their surgical treatment to be resolved but it appears to be affecting other conditions too. She warned: We canapost repeat the mistakes of the past. Roseanna added: I would like for mesh never to be used again but our petition is asking for its use to be suspended until there are proper guidelines. She wants the use of mesh devices and stitches to be suspended while a review of surgical procedures which implant any form of polyester, ­polypropylene or titanium – such as for hernias and hysterectomies – is carried out and guidelines established. Roseanna also called for all GP surgeries to have someone trained in mesh complications so people get the treatment and pain relief they need. Ironically, she campaigned with a friend treated with vaginal mesh for an end to that ­procedure, little realising the product was causing her own symptoms. After years of campaigns the Scottish Government completed a review into vaginal mesh implants used in the treatment of pelvic organ prolapse and urinary incontinence in women. Complications included pain during intercourse, bowel and bladder ­perforations, crippling nerve damage, lelong pain and mobility problems. In  the Scottish ­Government suspended the use of mesh for all but exceptional ­circumstances but its use was not halted until . The Scottish Government said two reviews were commissioned after concerns over mesh use in hernia repair. A spokeswoman said: The evidence supports the continued use of mesh in a iety of abdominal wall and groin hernia but of course, patient preference should be a key consideration. She said health boards were told to ask that alternative procedures be ­considered for those who wish them. Whilst transvaginal mesh is halted, some other procedures which use mesh are complex and long ­established, with few,any, viable alternatives. To suspend their use would leave a cohort of people with limited or no treatment options. For emotional support, you can call the Samaritans -hour helpline on  , email jo@samaritans.org, visit a Samaritans branch in person or go to the Samaritans website. title: sue gray report finds serious
story: Sue Gray report finds serious failings in No  - heres the internets best reactionsBrits have responded in the most British way possible to the release of Sue Grays eagerly anticipated report into the gatherings and parties at Downing Street during lockdownByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |commentsThe Sue Gray report is finally here, and as fury continues to spread up and down the country over Boris Johnsonaposs partygate, Brits have responded in the most British way possible - by flooding the internet with memes, because how  would we cope in a crisis  Grayaposs report found failures of leadership and judgement over parties which took place at No  Downing Street during lockdown restrictions, that simply should not have been allowed. Since its release, the Prime Minister has taken a verbal beating in the House of Commons, including a gut punch from former PM Theresa May, who told the house: Either he had not read the rules, or understood the rules, or thought they didnapost apply to him - which was it  Meanwhile, on social media, Brits have been having their own say on the scandal, in the form of hilarious memes and theyaposre taking no prisoners.  While millions are understandably upset by the findings, many have simply responded mocking the scarce -page document, which took weeks to produce. Gray has since suggested the report is simply an update and not the full report she had been preparing before the politan Police intervened.But, as we know, that will never stop the British public from going into full p***-taking mode and so far Twitter has been saturated with hilarious means making fun of the report.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here.With the Met Police still conducting its investigations into dozens of alleged parties and gatherings in No , the trial by social media doesnapost look set to end any time soon. Keep the memes coming.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news uk-news terrying-moment-storm-malik-mph-"Shocking moment entire roof is ripped off homeByKatie L Wilson:,  Jan |commentsStorm Malik’s mph terryingly strong gales ripped off the entire roof of a terraced house on Saturday.Toney Adoniadis captured the moment on video, as the roof of the house began to flap, before a gust of wind picked it up and brought the entire thing crashing down onto the road. “Here’s me worried about a tile that blew off my roof,” Toney said. The surrounding area of the house was cordoned off after the incident. Luckily, no injuries were reported as a result of the roof and its tiles falling onto the pavement below.On Saturday, the day the roof was ripped off, yellow and amber weather warnings for high winds had been issued across northern England, Scotland and Northern Ireland.  Tragically, three people died over the weekend as a result of Storm Malik’s gale-force winds. A nine-year-old boy, from Staffordshire, and a -year-old woman, from Aberdeen, were both killed by falling trees on Saturday. A -year-old man also died after a lorry overturned on the M. Around , homes across northern England and Scotland have been left without power in the wake of Storms Malik and Corrie over the weekend. Schools across Aberdeenshire were forced to close on Monday, as a result of power outages or storm damage. A -year-old hospitality worker, from Northumberland, has been without heating and electricity since Saturday morning. Clare Stirling-Turnbull said: “We have no electric, no heating or hot water - we do have a wood burner so can heat one room.Clare is unable to go to relatives’ houses, as one of the children in her family of six is currently isolating with Covid-.On Sunday night, gusts of mph were recorded at Stornoway in the Western Isles, which forecasters described as exceptionally strong. Met Office meteorologist, Alex Burkill, said: There is no wonder there were signicant impacts such as power outages and damage to buildings.It is very unfortunate that things were worse than that for some people. Fortunately, the Met Office said that the next few days would be a lot calmer, before a brief cold snap on Thursday. title: tv presenter cradled little girl
story: TV presenter cradled her little girl for hours after she died while on Lanzarote holidayThe couple and their family arrived on the Canary Island exhausted from the y journey but there was something not right with their daughter CiciDanielle Nicholls and Dean Holden Image: Manchester Evening News SyndicationByStephen ToppingGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |commentsA television presenter cradled her little girl for hours after she died in a holiday tragedy. Danielle Nicholls and former footballer Dean Holden faced the devastating heartache after spending nine hours waiting for a delayed flight to Lanzarote. They arrived on the Canary Island exhausted from the y journey but there was something not right with their daughter Cici. She was not her usual self, but there was aposnothing particularly tellingapos to warn the family about what would unfold.It had all been a bit of a perfect storm for us because weaposd travelled on the plane, Danielle told the Manchester Evening News. She was exhausted and really lethargic, but we put that down to her being  months and that weaposd been travelling all that time. We woke up once with her in the night and she was a little bit warm. We gave her a bit of Calpol, changed her nappy and put her back in bed. But by the time we got up the next morning we knew she wasnapost right. The couple found fame in the late s when Danielle became the face of CITV along with Stephen Mulhearn, while former footballer Dean was breaking into the first team at Bolton Wanderers. Dean enjoyed a career in the Football League, including a spell as captain of Oldham Athletic and Danielle scaled back her career to spend time raising their three young children - Joey, Ellis and Cici.  But after the family arrived in Lanzarote and Cici took a drink of water, her condition quickly deteriorated. She was rushed to a clinic on the island, where a helicopter was waiting to take her to the nearest intensive care unit. Within three hours, Cici had died. Thataposs whataposs scary for people I think - how quickly it can develop, said Danielle. She was our most laid back, chilled out kid. She had bright red hair and blue eyes, and she was dead unique looking - she looked like something out of the olden days because I used to dress her up in frills and that. Iaposd waited ages to have my little girl.Cici had suffered meningococcal septicemia - a bacterial infection which causes blood poisoning, leading to sepsis.Her death on May , , was just the beginning of the trauma and torment that would scar Danielle and Dean. The couple had to make arrangements to fly their dead daughter home, facing reluctance from airlines who feared it would aposupset other passengersapos. Danielle added: Sheaposd never, ever left my side, she hadnapost even stayed at grandmaaposs. It felt like I was in a horror movie. I canapost be scared by a horror movie anymore because my actual le was that frightening.  To hold your dead kid in your arms for two hours when she had died, just because I couldnapost let go of her. Danielle and Dean ed from the hospital to the villa, where Joey and Ellis had been staying with the presenteraposs sister Jodie and Deanaposs brother Matt. They broke the news to their young sons, then aged four and three, and the process of trying to come to terms with the tragedy began. I canapost remember the first days and weeks after she died because youaposre just in some kind of trance, said Dean.  The biggest thing is your personality just completely changes overnight - and then you start behaving in a way you never have before. Thataposs hard because people start saying aposoh youaposre not the person you used to beapos and you start fighting against it. Youaposre in your own head all the time. Having already suffered the heartache of losing their young daughter, Danielle and Dean were left fearing the worst when Ellis came down with a raging temperature on the following night. He was unwell for a couple of days but thankfully recovered. After ing to Worsley, Greater Manchester, the couple say they were only offered anti-depressants from their GP and decided against taking them.  Instead, they embarked on a process involving group therapy, hypnotherapy and a raft of coping mechanisms such as meditation and exercise, to stop them becoming aposjibbering wrecksapos. The emotional strain from what happened caused huge damage to the coupleaposs mental health and post-traumatic stress disordertook hold. Danielle said: Weaposre all very independent, weaposre all living our lives without community, which is OK until we forget there are still tragedies happening in peopleaposs lives. There would have been a time where I would talk about it and then I could feel ill for a week afterwards, said Danielle. We did that initially because we were in the spotlight, and it made us ill. Danielle and Dean struggled as they spoke to others and relived the death of their much-loved daughter. The couple say some were aposabruptapos to them, asking why they didnapost act dferently when Cici was ill, while others would cross the road to avoid speaking to them. Their experience has inspired them to be open and honest about what happened to Cici, rather than keeping quiet with a aposstf upper lipapos mentality. The couple found solace from a support group in Warrington for bereaved parents, known as Compassionate Friends, where they shared their experiences with other couples who had gone through the heartbreaking loss of a child. Dean was supported by the Professional Footballersapos Association, who helped him to see a psychotherapist. I think unless we all start talking about the bad things in le, people will feel like we felt - we felt like aliens. As they were coming to terms with the sudden loss of Cici, they still had to find work to keep providing for their two sons.  Dean had just been released by Rochdale and was approaching clubs for playing opportunities.For Danielle, who had been working on a freelance basis, Ciciaposs death came before she had been due to meet with the BBC about work on Bitesize .He said: Iaposd been to see counsellors, and it was useless, so I went to see a psychotherapist and learned how the brain works post-trauma. Iaposd be screwed without that, because I needed to understand why Iaposd gone from being this chilled out bloke to all of a sudden this raging lunatic.Danielle, Joey and Ellis, meanwhile, were supported by the charity Meningitis Now - with the boys having innovative art therapy and anger management sessions, while Danielle also had therapy sessions.The family say they donapost know where they would be without the help of Meningitis Now, which has recently asked the couple to become ambassadors for the charity. With collections at Deanaposs old football clubs Oldham, Bolton, Chesterfield, Shrewsbury and Walsall, they raised funds to give back to Meningitis Now and to fund sensory support equipment for their childrenaposs school. Only now, almost a decade since Ciciaposs death, do they feel able to be a strong voice for the charity. Danielle said: Every day you do the work. It doesnapost matter how long it is. When your kid dies, you never feel any less pain, no matter how much timeaposs gone by. Itaposs just like you learn to live with the pain. Now is the time that I want to say to people, itaposs OK to not be OK, but by being that person - not just by saying it. I know what itaposs like to have that missing part of you thataposs never going to come back.  Just taking the chance to say - I was that girl off kids TV, I had a kid died and everything went to s***, and Iaposve got mental health issues - but itaposs OK. Since Ciciaposs death, Dean and Danielle have gone on to have two more children - with eight-year-old Mitzi and three-year-old Chase joining Joey and Ellis, now aged  and  respectively. Cici is always in the familyaposs minds - with photos of the toddler put up in their Worsley home as well as in a bracelet on Danielleaposs wrist. Dean said: If there was a drug to erase Cici out of our memory - we would have lost  months of incredible memories, but they were outweighed by the pain. As you get through the therapy, that changes - now thereaposs no way weaposd ever want to forget her because we can manage the pain. We talk about Cici so much, thereaposs a massive picture of her at the top of the stairs. People will ask how many kids we have got, and itaposs a conversation wrecker but we donapost know any other way to address it, weaposll say weaposve had five but weaposve only got four. Then they feel horrible for asking, butwe just say weaposve got four we might as well just brush her out of our le. The couple use techniques like meditation, deep breathing and cold water immersion to help with their mental health ever day to avoid aposgoing to a dark placeapos. They are big advocates for therapy and the methods they have used to help them live with the pain of losing Cici. Although panic attacks can still take the couple back to the horrors of the day she died, they now feel able to bring their mental health back under control and avoid aposspirallingapos. Dean said: If Iaposm late for something, Iaposm going back to the day Cici died. I start shaking, I start panicking - and Iaposm just late, but my brain doesnapost know the dference. Weaposve spent a lot of time with a lot of good people, but there are ways of resetting by doing strategies - tapping, cold showers and whatever. “We do all kinds of weird and wonderful things that work. Dean and Danielle suffered yet more loss after Ciciaposs death, with five miscarriages in the years between Mitzi and Chase being born. Covid brought added strain - with lockdown robbing the family of their coping mechanisms following Ciciaposs death, while Deanaposs work at Bristol City kept him away from home. But now, the pair are looking forward to a bright future with their careers.Having done live Twitch streams online for gaming on the BiigNoobs channel in recent months, Danielle is hoping to get back on TV and radio, with work in the pipeline.She also took on a comedy course last summer to try a completely new experience. Danielle said: I love making people laugh, I didnapost realise how much Iaposd enjoy it. Itaposs good - but Iaposm proper scared before I go up. Iaposm doing open mics and stuff because I want to learn the trade - I want to get a bit of cred from the other comedians. Dean added: When she goes in front of a camera or goes on stage, her eyes light up. Thataposs what she was born to do. Meanwhile, having left his role at Bristol City last season, Dean is now much closer to home as assistant manager for Stoke City. Having lived through so much pain over the past decade, the couple say they are grateful for what they have, and are looking forward to the next chapter. Danielle said: Weaposve had so much sadness and tragedy, but it doesnapost mean that weaposre miserable people who donapost have a laugh, in fact quite the opposite. news us-news meghan-markle-harry-release-statement-"Meghan and Harry release trailer for Archewell Audio podcast in ByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments Prince Harry and Meghan Markle say they have been expressing concerns to Spoty about Covid- misinformation but will continue to work with the .The couple, who have been supporting vaccine equity, signed a lucrative deal with the streaming giant to host and produce podcasts, estimated to be worth around  million US dollars , in late . In a statement on Sunday, the coupleaposs charity Archewell said they had been expressing concerns to Spoty about the issue since the charityaposs inception, and continue to do so to ensure changes to its  are made to help address this public health crisis. It comes after a number of artists ditched the  due to controversial content such as The Joe Rogan Experience podcast, which has been known to air vaccine-sceptical views.  An Archewell spokesperson said the couple are committed to continuing their work with the streaming . Hundreds of millions of people are affected by the serious harms of rampant mis- and disinformation every day, the spokesperson said. Last April, our co-founders began expressing concerns to our partners at Spoty about the all too real consequences of Covid- misinformation on its . We have continued to express our concerns to Spoty to ensure changes to its  are made to help address this public health crisis.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. We look to Spoty to meet this moment and are committed to continuing our work together as it does. It comes after Joni Mitchell announced on Saturday that she would remove her catalogue from Spoty in solidarity with Neil Young.Youngaposs music is being taken down from the  after he reportedly offered it an ultimatum to remove either his work or The Joe Rogan Experience podcast.Following Youngaposs reported concerns, Spoty said it aimed to balance both safety for listeners and freedom for creators and had removed more than , podcast episodes related to Covid since the start of the pandemic.  Later on Sunday, Daniel Ek, CEO of Spoty, said: We know we have a critical role to play in supporting creator expression while balancing it with the safety of our users. In that role, it is important to me that we donapost take on the position of being content censor while also making sure that there are rules in place and consequences for those who violate them. Mr Ek also announced that the company has published its long-standing Platform Rules after admitting it had not been transparent around the policies that guide our content more broadly. He said the  is also working to add a content advisory to any podcast episode that includes a discussion about Covid-.  I trust our policies, the research and expertise that inform their development, and our aspiration to apply them in a way that allows for broad debate and discussion, within the lines, he added. Last week it was reported that Spoty were taking Harry and Meghanaposs deal into their own hands after little content has emerged. The company are hiring a number of in-house producers to help deliver on the deal after waiting more than a year for any material. They are recruiting new staff to work with Harry and Meghanaposs Archewell Audio in Los Angeles for podcasts that feature the voices of high profile women.” One advert for a senior producer role at Gimlet Projects, Spotyaposs in-house production arm, states: We’re currently assembling a show team that will build and launch a new original show with Archewell featuring the voices of high profile women. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex’s only effort so far for Spoty has been a -minute aposholiday specialapos in December . It featured their friends James Corden and Elton John. A source told The Sun: Spoty has been waiting a long time for some content from Harry and Meghan and now it appears they have finally taken matters into their own hands. Hiring a raft of in-house talent on Spoty’s side will ensure they finally squeeze something out of them as they bid to honour their contract. news us-news meghan-markles-most-candid-posts-"Prince Harry and Meghan include children in festive messageByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan |commentsIt was the place where Meghan Markle would post her inner-most thoughts, post fun photos and share her favourite hacks and recipes. The Tig was Meghanaposs successful lestyle blog that she ran before marrying Prince Harry while an actress on the hit legal drama Suits. It also included interviews with her celebrity friends including Serena Williams and Priyanka Chopra.She shut down the site in  - just months before her engagement to Harry was announced. However, according to the Daily Mail, LA lawyer Marjorie Witter Norman filed a new application to trademark the blogaposs name in July last year, according to legal records.  It was filed under a Delaware-based holding company called Frim Fram Inc, linked to Meghanaposs business manager Andrew Meyer. Itaposs a move that has raised hopes that Meghan - who stepped down as a working royal along with Harry in March  - may one-day re-launch the blog. Here, we take a look back at some of Meghanaposs most candid posts on The Tig... Constant battle Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. In a post to mark her rd birthday in , Meghan opened up about her younger years - before she shot to international fame - giving an insight into her le. She called the post Birthday Suit and accompanying the post was a beautul image of Meghan - appearing to not be wearing a top.She wrote: My s were brutal – a constant battle with myself, judging my weight, my style, my desire to be as cool as hip as smart as aposwhateverapos as everyone . Meanwhile, Meghan also talked in the post about her teenage years and trying to fit in at school. She added: My teens were even worse – grappling with how to fit in, and what that even meant. My high school had cliques: the black girls and white girls, the Filipino and the Latina girls. Being biracial, I fell somewhere in between. She said every day at lunch she would keep herself busy with school societies like French club and a student body that took place between noon and pm so she wouldnapost have to eat on her own. But she recalled a breakthrough moment in her le when attending an audition in her mid-s. She explained: I must have been about  when a casting director looked at me during an audition and said aposYou need to know that you’re enough. Less makeup, more Meghanapos. Unladylike habits  In another candid post, Meghan made a confession about struggling to give up unladylike habits as part of her New Yearaposs resolutions - just months before she met Prince Harry. She wrote: Run a marathon. Stop biting my nails. Stop swearing. Re-learn French. These make my New Year’s resolution list nearlysingle year.The marathon hasnapost happened. The swearing comes in lulls triggered by being overworked or feeling mighty cheeky after a couple of drinks.Then thereaposs the French – a language I studied through high school and then lost as I immersed myself in speaking Spanish with the Argentinians during my stint in Buenos Aires.I have put my little Rosetta Stone headset in my eager ears every year, resolving to do interviews en français, but much to my chagrin, it hasnapost stuck.And when it comes to the biting of the nails – well, it still happens with a turbulent flight or a stressful day. Itaposs unladylike. But then again, so is the swearing. Dammit.Sweet tribute to dad  Meghanaposs relationship with her estranged father Thomas has been strained for many years.Itaposs thought the pair havenapost seen each other since she married Harry and he is yet to meet his grandchildren Archie and Lilibet.However, when Meghan was running her blog, it seemed she was close to her dad and wrote a gushing post about him revealing the heartwarming present he once bought her for Christmas.She explained how her hardworking daddy went to Toys R Us to buy a boxed set of Barbie dolls which she had been yearning for - at a time she was struggling with her biracial identity. However there was a problem - they either came as a black family or a white one. So when at Toys R Us faced with the boxes of Barbies in front of him, Thomas aposbroke the rulesapos and took them apart to make a custom family for his little girl. Meghan recalled: When I was about seven, I had been fawning over a boxed set of Barbie dolls.  It was called The Heart Family and included a mom doll, a dad doll, and two children. This perfect nuclear family was only sold in sets of white dolls or black dolls. I don’t remember coveting one over the other, I just wanted one. On Christmas morning, swathed in glitter-flecked wrapping paper, there I found my Heart Family: a black mom doll, a white dad doll, and a child in each color. My dad had taken the sets apart and customized my family. I picture him standing there in Toys R Us, moms glaring at him for taking the toys apart, perhaps an employee saying aposexcuse me sir, you can’t do thatapos — as my dad carefully separated the boxed sets to make one that echoed my reality. One that showed me that I shouldmake my own box. Post about Kate Middleton  In a twist of a fate, Meghan also blogged about the Duke and Duchess of Cambridgeaposs wedding - seven years before her own royal wedding.She wrote the pomp surrounding Kate and Williamaposs  wedding and how she grew up dreaming of becoming a princess.A section published by The Sun states: Little girls dream of being princesses. I, for one, was all about She-Ra, Princess of Power.For those of you unfamiliar with the aposs cartoon reference, She-Ra is the twin sister of He-Man and a sword-wielding royal rebel known for her strength.Weaposre definitely not talking about Cinderella here.Grown women seem to retain this childhood fantasy. Just look at the pomp and circumstance surrounding the royal wedding and endless conversation about Princess Kate.Juggling celebrity le  In one of Meghanaposs most popular posts, Meghan offered her candid thoughts on how to juggle celebrity le with giving back and doing her day job.The ,-word post was published in October , months after starting her relationship with Prince Harry.I’m consistently asked how I keep a foot in two contrasting worlds – one in the entertainment industry, predicated on wealth and indulgence, and the other in humanitarian work.To me, it’s less of a question of how can you do this, and more a question of how can you not, Meghan wrote.She also describes her upbringing in Los Angeles, Calornia, with her free-spirited clinical therapist mom and the most hardworking father you can imagine, and how, even at , she wanted to become an independent, strong woman.Meghan added: While my le shts from refugee camps to red carpets, I choose them both because these worlds can, in fact, coexist. And for me, they must. My eleven year old self would be proud, because while I may not have realized it at the time, I, in fact, have always had a foot in the world of entertainment as well as the world of public service my le now is simply a more heightened version of the very reality in which I grew up. And, truth be told, it’s the most beautul gt I never knew I always had.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Prince HarryMeghan MarkleRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Garden shed up for rent at £, a month as landlord branded greedyA property up for rent in Bristol has been mocked online as people say it looks like a garden shed, and even though its tiny it will still set you back £, a monthA rental property in Bristol has been compared to a shed Image: Kennedy News Digs Bristol RightmoveByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Jan |comments A city rental property has been likened to a aposgarden shedapos - and even though itaposs small it still costs a staggering £, per month.The hut appears to be made of wood and is located behind another property with other flats inside, and while itaposs described as premium others think itaposs just a shed. It does come with a fitted kitchen and integrated appliances, but it is very small - and itaposs not exactly cheap, eventhe price does include all bills.People have said the property, in Bristol, is a good example of how aposbonkersapos the housing market is in the city now - but others have said the owner is aposgreedyapos.What do you think of the property  Let us know in the comments...The flat, which appears to be represented by Digs Bristol, is described as a aposhigh-quality developmentapos and appears to be newly built. The advert for the property has been shared online and many house-hunters were quick to comment on the post. Lynn Parfitt, from Bristol, said: This is terrible. Itaposs up for rent for over £k a month. It actually recommended a couple! Itaposs a flipping shed. The rental market has gone bonkers in Bristol. Feel so sorry for young people especially when they are looking to leave home. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. The market is making it impossible for them to live in their own city. Rani Fernandez was shocked and said: Oh my le! I pay a little over £k a month for a  bed. Even that’s steep, this is greedy and unjust. The greed of some people! It’s exploitation. Lesley Gillilan said: Horrible. Kerrey Mitchell said: That is appalling. Pam Morgan said: You could buy a two-bed ground floor flat for £, on Hampton road in the early - mid s. Inside, the property has a widescreen TV and a one-person dining table, and the advert says it would apossuit a coupleapos. In another area of the renovated outhouse, new tenants have access to a compact shower cubicle, sink and toilet. Rightmove and Digs Bristol were contacted for comment.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: im proud being catfish people
story: Im proud of being a catfish - people say my transformations should be illegalJordyn Lyne has said people often tell her that her stunning makeup transformations should be illegal, but she loves sharing her before-and-after videos onlineJordyn Lyne is a self-confessed catfish thanks to her makeup transformations Image: @jordynlyne TikTokByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Jan |comments For many of us, putting on makeup can help us feel more comfortable in our own skin - and thereaposs nothing wrong with putting on a little glam, evenitaposs just to pop down the shops. But one self-confessed catfish on TikTok has been leaving people baffled with her stunning makeup transformations, as her before-and-after videos show her giving herself a double chin and posing with spots and red cheeks before using makeup to completely change her look. Jordyn Lyne, who posts under the username @jordynlyne, has racked up more than . million likes on TikTok with over , followers thanks to her transformation videos. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. And the beauty often puts playful captions on her clips to draw attention to how dferent she looks with makeup on, as one video was titled: Itaposs a lie #catfish. Jordynaposs videos have attracted thousands of positive comments from other women who have praised her honesty, especially in clips where she is seen shaving the stubble from her chin before getting glammed up for a night out. One person wrote: You actually look amazing. While another said: Youaposre beautul with or without makeup, forget those rude people.  And a third wrote: You are amazing! No joke, I would love to have confidence like you. Keep going! But some of the womanaposs male viewers are less impressed by her transformation videos, and Jordyn has been subjected to her fair share of hate from people who believe sheaposs the reason they have trust issues. One troll commented: Guys, thataposs why you have to take her to the pool on the first date -you understand what Iaposm saying. As a second nasty viewer replied: Ah yes, and you ask us why we have trust issues  While someone  posted: This should be illegal. Jordyn takes the negative comments in her stride though, and recently took one message that compared her to the evil Miss Trunchbull from Matilda as an opportunity to show off another impressive makeup video. The comment read: Very much Miss Trunchbull from Matilda vibes. And Jordyn responded by posting a video in which she proudly put on a mixture of foundation, under-eye concealer, baby powder for setting, bronzer, blusher and lip gloss to completely change up her look.What do you think  Let us know in the comments below.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TikTokViralOnline trollsMake-up" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mcdonalds employee explains you shouldnt
story: McDonalds employee explains why you shouldnt bother ordering large friesA McDonalds employee from the US has claimed theres no point in ordering large fries with your meal - because staff are often told to ration the portion sizesThe employee claimed they get told to ration large portions of fries Image: nnennaaaaa TIKTOKByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Jan |comments We all know that McDonaldaposs food isnapost exactly good for you, but when the time comes to give in and order from the fast-food giant, many of us will take the opportunity to go all out - and that means ordering a large portion of fries. But according to one McDonaldaposs employee in the US, going large doesnapost necessarily mean youaposre going to get your moneyaposs worth, as they claimed thereaposs a secret rationing process that takes place any time a customer orders a large. The employee, who posts on TikTok under the username @nnennaaaaa, shared a video from a recent sht at the fast-food chain in which they served up a large portion of fries in the signature McDonaldaposs box - but admitted they purposefully pinched the bottom of the box so that fewer fries would fit in. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. They wrote on the clip: How we make our large fries - we donapost open the cardboard all the way. Saves us more fries for other customers. Commenters on the viral video - which has racked up over , views - were split by the employeeaposs claims though, as some other McDonaldaposs staffers insisted theyaposve never been told to ration their portion sizes. One person said: Not all McDonaldaposs employees are lazy. You guys are giving all us other hard workers a bad name! As another wrote: Wrong. I worked at McDonald’s for  years and our head manager would have had our headswe had tried to pull something like that.  While a third insisted: That’s probably just in your location. I’ve worked at like  locations and I’m always told to open it and pack it. There were also comments from other workers who agreed with the claims, stating theyaposd also been instructed by management not to open the box the whole way. Someone said: I worked at McDonaldaposs and I can confirm they told us to do that. Now when I order I make sure they fill them. And someone  posted: I worked at McDonaldaposs for nearly  years and this is completely correct. The managers at the stores I worked in got madyou opened it up all the way. But many of the comments were simply from disgruntled McDonaldaposs fans who felt theyaposd been misled by the fast-food giant and werenapost getting what they paid for. One fumed: Itaposs nice to know that weaposre intentionally getting ripped off. We pay for a large fry because we want a large fry, not because we like the bigger box. As another said: So you get charged for a large but don’t really get a large. Nice. Ripping off your customers. Why not just say you can’t order large fries  McDonaldaposs US have been contacted for comment.What do you think of the employeeaposs claims  Let us know in the comments below.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON McDonalds CorporationMcDonaldsFast foodFoodTikTokViral" data-immediate"data-immediate"Serve the food you really want to eat by signing up for our tips and recipes and never be bored by your cooking againSign UpInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: psychic who claims can predict
story: Psychic who claims she can predict relationships reveals  dates you could fall in love in Inbaal Honigman, , has been giving psychic readings for more than  years, using the stars to predict love and relationships - and now shes revealed the top days to find love in Inbaal has revealed the top days to find love this year Image: PA Real LeByRikki LoftusJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan |commentsA psychic who can see romance written in the stars has predicted the best days to find love in . Inbaal Honigman, , calls on planetary forces to make her predictions - looking to the moon for guidance. The psychic of more than  years lives in West Yorkshire with her husband and four kids. She said: “New moons are a really important time of the month because they symbolise new beginnings, soyou’re seeing someone for a first date then you’re going to skew the odds slightly in your favour by planning it for the new moon.“We’re in a dferent sign each month so, for this month, the new moon we have is in Aquarius.“Aquarius is a sign for intellectual pursuits, soyou plan a first date for the Aquarius new moon, which is on February , then to skew it further in your favour, plan a date to the opera or a museum, something that involves an intellectual activity.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Inbaal, originally from Israel, says she grew up in a family where no one held strong spiritual beliefs like her. “I was raised not believing in mystical stuff, she said. As a family, we went to synagogue once a year to keep my great grandad happy, but I had no spiritual leads at all. “Still, I always knew I had some sort of spiritual gt. At school, when a teacher asked a question, I would always know the answer. Everyone thought I was just a clever girl, but it was stuff I had no prior knowledge of. “If we played a game of aposWhat’s under the cups apos or aposWhich hand am I holding an item in apos I always got it right. When she left Israel at  years old, Inbaal says she discovered tarot cards - and she reckons her predictions have come true on several occasions.  During the financial crash, I somehow managed to sell my flat in London to move to Yorkshire and made the move just four days before I gave birth to my firstborn. I was also told I was infertile, but managed to conceive my first two children naturally. I manested my little family.Since first becoming a psychic in , Inbaalaposs career has skyrocketed and sheaposs now a regular on TV - appearing on Stephaposs Packed Lunch on Channel . Using the moon to guide her love predictions, Inbaal said:Pisces is one of the most romantic signs, so a very romantic day this year is September , the Pisces full moon. This would be a very good day for a proposal.Each day of the week can also influence romance, as they are all named after gods and goddesses, according to Inbaal. She said: Friday is named after Freyja, the goddess of love, and is the perfect day to plan a first date. You really increase your chances of getting a second date by picking a Friday. Tuesday is named after Mars, they are war gods so not a good time for a first date, but perhaps a good time for a hook-up, because the energies are fiery.Did you fall in love in an unusual or unexpected way  Get in touch at jessica.taylor@reachplc. She added: “Saturday is named after Saturn, which is a very serious and mature god. It’s a time to make big plans, but not for finding new love. As online dating has grown, Inbaal says itaposs best to steer clear of first dates when Mercury is in retrograde. She said: “You should probably avoid meeting new people as much as possible during this time. Mercury is the planet of communication and it affects the way we talk. “When Mercury is in retrograde we might say something but mean something  and end up insulting the person we were trying to compliment. “Mercury also affects social media, emails and everything to do with communication. We could send a message and end up sending a nude to our mum instead of the person we’re trying to reach, or we could end up forgetting to press send on an important message. “With online dating, you have to be careful, because one  move and you could get blocked and you’ll never see them again.” Mercury is currently in retrograde and will be until  February - so those looking for love should beware. Inbaal continued: “The stars intel, they do not compel, which means you use what you like within astrology to help you along, but you don’t take onboard any of the worrying predictions and agonise over them. “If a prediction doesn’t sound like something in your favour, leave it at the door. That extends to my work with manesting, you just need to focus solely on the positives, and you will have a wonderful year.”Inbaal’s top five days to find love: · nd March – New Moon in Pisces· st April – New Moon in Aries · th April – New Moon in Taurus · th May – New Moon in Gemini · th June – New Moon in CancerTop times to avoid dating· th Jan–rd Feb· th May–rd June· th September–nd October· After th DecemberInbaal has teamed up with dating app, Safer Date, to explore the most romantic days of the Gregorian calendar Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON LoveSpiritual Le" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
